text: hey quick question: im thinking of transitioning our cms website from non-boilerplate (clean6 template) to a boilerplate, but on a specific date... im hoping to use the boilerplate for the "v2", but am a bit confused about the idea of "pages" when using the boilerplate vs not-using the boilerplate.  are pages controlled / created via the boilerplate or are they created via content editors?
Hey Quinn! What’s happening?  When you are referring to switching to boilerplate, what do you mean exactly?
With “boilerplate” are you referring to the coded HTML files?
hey kevin! correct, so it looks like HS is moving towards <https://github.com/HubSpot/cms-theme-boilerplate>
I'm actually figuring this out at this point, and i think it makes sense... basically this is an approach that uses version control + local dev to run the templates
i was just confused since it looked like it was generating actual pages, not templates
Gotcha! Just wanted to make sure we’re talking about same thing.  I’m actually in the process (as i type) of converting CLEAN over to a “theme” (boilerplate).
getting an error trying to upload the boilerplate:

```[ERROR] Uploading file "/Users/quinnchaffee/code/finalforms/v3-finalforms-website/src/templates/contact.html" to "v3-finalforms-website/templates/contact.html" failed
[ERROR] Error validating template.
[ERROR] line 0: Template does not include the tag {{ standard_header_includes }}.
[ERROR] line 0: Template does not include the tag {{ standard_footer_includes }}. Needed for HubSpot analytics```
im guessin i just need to include those (since the boilerplate is for groups that havent enabled analytics or something?)
actually... those are in the layout... so for some reason the `layout` isnt getting evaluated correctly?
You can technically set up version control via GitHub using templates (i believe).  Themes (boilerplate) just have a bunch of other new advantages.
ah... seems it was only on the first sync
all good now
yeah i was initially going that route (using `hs upload` and `hs fetch`)
but this seems way more intuitive in creating templates and modules, plus i :heart: version control + all the code in one place
btw, dunno if this helps you, but <https://github.com/HubSpot/cms-theme-boilerplate/pull/98>
:point_up:  enables github actions as the repo intends i think
Thanks!
if you arent into that, i wrote some other package.json helpers:

```  "scripts": {
    "eslint": "eslint src",
    "lint": "eslint src && prettier --list-different 'src/**/*.js' 'src/**/*.json'",
    "push": "hs upload src TODO_NAME_DIRECTORY",
    "watch": "hs watch src TODO_NAME_DIRECTORY",
    "prettier:write": "prettier --write 'src/**/*.js' 'src/**/*.json'"
  }```
That’s super helpful. Thank you!
